DOC.HEAD: US Troops Come Upon a Bizarre Scene
EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch.
EDs: CORRECTS 1st graf to make witches Brazilian instead of Panamanian; subs 3rd graf, Snell said to add detail; inserts 6th graf, bgng: Other
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers who stormed one of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's guest houses here narrowly missed capturing four Brazilian voodoo witches who performed rituals for his protection, officials said Friday. The so-called ``witch house,'' a fortified structure specially built for Noriega, contained an estimated 50 pounds of cocaine, a bucket of blood, voodoo artifacts and a brewery for making concoctions and potions, Col. Mike Snell, the officer in charge of the area, said. Snell said it was not known whether the blood was human or animal or for what the potions were used. Officers said some of the cocaine had been wrapped in a banana leaf and placed in the freezer. Gen. Maxwell Thurmand, commander of the Panama-based Southern Command, said at a press briefing that Noriega's ``voodoo practitioners ... practiced rituals for Noriega's protection.'' Lt. Curtis Vinyard said the house had apparently been occupied until shortly before it was stormed by U.S. troops. Other military officers said the house was where Noriega ``kept his Brazilian withces.'' ``There was still a candle burning,'' he said. Some of the soldiers who stormed the house said there were smoldering cigarettes in ashtrays and women had left their purses, and they believed they might have come close to capturing Noriega himself. In any event, Noriega was still at large. The house, on the seacoast near here and close to several U.S. military bases, was stormed by U.S. soldiers on Tuesday, about six hours after the U.S. invasion began. An American soldier who would not give his name but was familiar with the incident said troops who saw the house spread the word that one room was apparently devoted to the occult, with blood and entrails. Reporters were also shown odd trappings in two offices used by Noriega. His office in Panama's military barracks at Fort Amador had two display cases full of plastic frogs, framed pictures of Adolf Hitler, Mother Theresa and Moammar Ghadafi, and dozens of electronic toys such as a video wristwatch. U.S. officials showed reporters Christmas trees, more electronics and more frogs at his former headquarters office downtown. Snell said collections of pornography wre found in both offices and the Fort Amador house was stocked with Noriega's private brands of cigars and champagne. U.S. intelligence officials scoured the offices in the hope of finding records would help trace Noriega's assets. Sgt. 1st Class Joseph Torregrossa said the Fort Amador office also contained expensive prints and ``a lot of expensive weapons, mostly automatic. He had German Lugers, Israeli Uzis, all sorts of real sophisticated stuff.'' Thurmand told reporters, ``He was clearly dedicated to outfitting a substantial force, outfitting dignity battalions, which in the long run would have given us a tremendous challenge in this area.'' Travel restrictions, including a nighttime curfew, were still in effect Friday, and new fighting was reported with men loyal to Noriega attacking the headquarters of the U.S. Southern Command. A two-hour tour through a bombed-out shopping district that once was a Noriega stronghold showed scenes of near chaos as thousands of looters seized refrigerators, microwaves, automobile tires, gasoline and other goods. They cheerfully stopped, however, to shout ``Viva Bush, Viva Bush'' or ``Bush, Bush, Bush'' as they waved to soldiers and journalists. One held up a knife sharpener and joked, ``It's a present from Bush.'' Noriega's nine-building headquarters was a smouldering hulk, its windows blown out by tank and artillery fire. It was closely guarded by dozens of U.S. troops. Less than a mile away, the body of a man, face down and shirtless, lay trapped in the crushed wreckage of a sedan. A U.S. infantry sergeant said an armored personnel carrier rolled over the car after the driver was seen passing out AK-47 rifles. An old section of the city around Noriega headquarters contained many of Panama City's poor and homeless, but they had largely abandoned it, taking refuge in quarters provided by U.S. military at the American-owned Balboa High School in the suburbs, U.S. officials said.
